Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2014 10:47AM justachapter wrote: Coop, you are handling this amazingly well!  I have watched both your video's and it is good to see the emotions we all go through with this.  One day life is swimming along and then suddenly we are confronted with this major bump we need to work through.  I'm being lazy, but do you know that you are ER-/PR- already?  I found out I was ER+/PR+ the day I got my biopsy results.   Hugs to you and you've got this!

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2014 10:22AM justachapter wrote: Good luck!  I just joined this board, had biopsy today and sounds like mine was a lot like your previous one.
Posts.Title: 6 month follow up mammo tomorrow Petitegal127 Petitegal127

Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2014 02:53PM justachapter wrote: I work in benefits. A few things, if you can't get anywhere with the insurance company appeal it. Appeal it on the grounds you went to an INN facility and you didn't have a choice with the anesthesiologist. Second, if you met your OOP max, you shouldn't owe any money, everything should be covered at 100% for the remainder of the year, if your benefits are on a calendar year. Unless, there is a different OOP Max for INN vs OON? Do not pay the full bill, you should not have to, if you went INN. Usually most insurance companies will pay at INN level or won't and then it eventually is reprocessed as INN, if you only have INN and did everything in your power to do what you were supposed to do. Good Luck!
Posts.Title: Anesthesiology and insurance network MeToo14 Kicks

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2014 06:08PM - edited Apr 2, 2014 08:10PM by justachapter Thanks for your replies ladies.  A hemangioma is an often incidental finding many times in liver and in spine, but usually multiple in spine and these are always benign lesions. They don't often cause pain and are just left there.  What I have found is they are very rare in the sacral region, more often those are mets.  HOWEVER, I'm not looking at this as that is what it is, the MRI was in January and this pain is nagging me again, but no one has been able to identify what it is.  And I never expected to be diagnosed with any type of cancer when I did all the testing to rule everything out. What is even more bothersome and I will talk to my Dr. about all this and my concern to have someone decipher what it is that was seen is that a lesion at that area can affect bladder, bowel etc.  I had a partial hysterectomy almost 7 years ago.  After surgery I had a neurogenic bladder for 3 months, I had to self-cath.  No one could figure out what was going on or what happened.  They started assuming I had a muscle issue (ie MS) and the trauma of surgery had caused it to manifest itself.  I lived in TX at the time and they referred me to Baylor or a place in Houston to see a specialist.  I was so over Dr's, tests and the unknown I didn't do that and it eventually got better.  So, I wonder if whatever is there was the cause then too. The pain has been intermittent for a year now, but in the same area sometimes bothersome and sometimes very painful.
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2014 08:57PM - edited Apr 3, 2014 12:52AM by justachapter cypher, I never thought of any connection until I went to Dr. Google :).  But, there is no injury, which is what was  so odd about what happened. I just wonder if this "lesion" has always been there and it caused my issues 7 years ago as that area S2 controls those functions.  8mm is very small though too.  The whole mets thing is what frightened me as that area it is rare to have a hemangioma and no Dr. has proven it is one or the other.  I put it on the back burner, once I got the dx of the DCIS.  It was the recurrent pain that reminded me I'm at a perfect facility to have some one give me direction or re-read the CD. Thank you for your responses, I truly appreciate it.
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2014 11:06PM justachapter wrote: I don't know if anyone remembers me here, I posted on April 2nd about a strange MRI finding in January that led to the BC diagnosis?  The MRI was of my sacro area and at the S2 there was an 8mm focus that they couldn't confirm, but said it possibly an atypical hemangioma (very rare to be there) or potentially metastasis.  My Dr's had said to have my well woman as I was behind and if everything was clear (thinking if it had spread it was from breast or pelvic) we would revisit and decide what to do. BC is DCIS, but oncologist reviewed everything and they are doing a Petscan on me. I'm assuming they couldn't tell by looking at the CD or they have to rule it out?  A few here suggested that, so wanted to let you know I'm having a Petscan in a few days.  Today they said they were going to try and do it this week, but didn't hear today, so maybe Friday or early next week.   I just need to find out why I am in so much pain in that area.  And the bottom of my foot has some numbness.   How do they decide to do bone vs Pet? Thank You!
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2014 01:14PM - edited Apr 2, 2014 04:00PM by justachapter Hi Ladies, I have a rather odd finding, and had put it on the back burner, but now it is bugging me again since I feel the pain.  I see my surgeon next week and am going to ask her opinion, but want to throw it out there to see if anyone has run into this type of incidental issue.  I met with oncologist this week, and start radiation in about 3 weeks.  Hadn't talked to either one as I was just thinking about this again last night. I was having some severe back back on my lower right side near my sacro joint (still have it).  Had an MRI as Dr. thought maybe sacroiliitis.  MRI was not with contrast.  Findings came back with no sign of sacroiliitis, but read "There is a focus of increased T2 signal within the sacral body at the level about S2 measuring about 8mm in size, this is hyperintense on T2 and T2 fat-sat images.  The lesion is poorly identifiable on the T1-weighted images.  Differential could include an atypical hemangioma without fat or potentially the presence of metastasis.  I do not see additional lesions.   What I have found is hemangioma's are rare in that region. What complicates this is, I said "what do we do to confirm or deny that report?"  Dr said have you had your well woman exam as mostly likely any metastasis would come from breast or pelvic?? If everything comes back negative, we will revisit this.   So, I did all that (I had not had a mammo in 3 years, various reasons, but none good).  Well, lo and behold I am dx'd with DCIS Grade 3.  Well, that is contained so it has nothing to do with that.  I had an MRI before surgery on both breasts and nothing additional showed up.   I still have that pain and that finding still bothers me.  Now that I'm with a multidisciplinary center (MD Anderson) I want to talk to someone about reviewing the MRI CD. Can someone have metastasis and not know the source? Thank You for any input.
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2014 01:09AM justachapter wrote: Thanks chrissyb!  I understand DCIS is contained and that is what is strange about all this.  I only found out about the DCIS because of the strange MRI, they thought if it was cancer that had spread it probably came from breast or pelvic as I was delinquent on my mammo etc.  So, they had me do all those tests and DCIS was found (really incidentally), but we still didn't know what was on my sacrum that started it all.  Collapsed and herniated disc, all that stuff are ruled out.  Oncologist has my CD and report, and after reviewing it ordered the PET.  Hopefully it will be my first and last, but get us closer to what the issue is.
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2014 08:50PM justachapter wrote: Thank you ladies.  Actually my gyn sends you to an imaging place and then they have nurse navigators that take you through the process.   So, they will get me to the next steps.   My Dr. always gets the results and called me with the suspicious mammo, and then called today no wanting me to have to wait until Thurs.  But like you two have said, I didn't process much of what she told me.  It was the Dr who did the biopsy that said she was pretty sure it was benign.  I do have to say, the place I go is fabulous and very compassionate and caring. I'm concerned about two things, the lump I found before biopsy that didn't show on the mammo.  And during biopsy I got a large hematoma at the site of the lump and calcs.  Am now wondering about the lump since it was positive.  Will the hematoma need to heal?  I know no one here can answer those questions, but ones on the top of my head at the moment. Thank you for taking the time to reply.

Posts.Title: Would you mind sharing your age at time of diagnosis? ByFaith Gussy

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2014 03:50PM - edited Jul 9, 2014 03:53PM by justachapter Each of situations is so unique.  My DCIS was small, but it was Grade 3 and my margins all the way around were only 1mm.  That still frightens me (I'm small, not a lot of tissue).  I am only 46 and then I'm ER+, but PR-.  Still considered +, but I've read it may not have the same full effect as someone who is fully ER and PR+. However, what I wanted to chime in on.  I go to MD Anderson and I asked about the 10 years as the study was making full steam in May.  I went on Tami almost a month ago (knock on wood, no SE's).  My oncologist said the change from 5-10 years was based on one study and as an academic hospital they are not going to change the protocol based on one study.  If in the next 5 years more come out, I could be on it for 10 years, but for now it is 5.   So certain area's standard of care, but there is still a lot of gray area.  1mm margins for many is too close?
Posts.Title: When Doctor's Disagree!!! Mouche Wyowild

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2014 07:17PM justachapter wrote: wyowild, did you go to a  general surgeon?  Or how did you come upon the surgeon you used? I had a lot of bleeding from my biopsy and ended up with a large hematoma that was removed during my lumpectomy.  I can't imagine a 2.7cm grade 2 tumor not having radiation? My tumor was fairly small, the bigger issue for me was that it was grade 3, small margins, near my chest wall and I'm PR- which seems to put me in a category with a more aggressive tumor.  I ended up having to do 7 weeks of radiation and 2 of those were boosts. The imaging center where I had the biopsy gave me a referral to a breast surgeon, etc.  But I had a friend who had just gone through this and asked her who she had used.  She went to MD Anderson and I went there and have had a multidisciplinary approach that I think benefits any and all cancer patients.  Everything is under one roof, your team works together and if there is any question about treatment it goes to the board. RADS was not to bad and amazingly I am normally hypersensitive to drugs, but have had virtually no SE's with Tamoxifen and have now been on it about 6 weeks.  I take it at night and was having insomnia, but MO NP said that isn't normally an SE and we (both of us) attributed it to my my mind not being about to shut off.  She said to take .25mg of Benadryl before I got to bed and that seems to be doing the trick. Good Luck!
Posts.Title: When Doctor's Disagree!!! Mouche Wyowild

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2014 03:33PM justachapter wrote: I would be livid with your original Dr.  Until you have a biopsy done, you don't have concrete answers, but I would demand to know why you never received a call and check to see if he/she has your records.  That lacks complete professionalism.  Good luck with the biopsy.
Posts.Title: Scared out of my mind!!!! Mompv Mompv

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2014 01:29PM justachapter wrote: Nancy, I had a similar issue and cancer had to be ruled out as the summary included potential metastasis in T2 Sacral area from an MRI.  That area almost never has benign stuff.  I had a Petscan and it nothing showed up on the Petscan. Only an area of breast that lit up like a Christmas tree, but at the time they are still chalking it up to inflammation from surgery. I understand your fears, but keep taking that Xanax (I had to as I had a panic attack at my first RADS because of the impending Petscan).  Will keep you in my thoughts.
Posts.Title: Unbelievable Nancy2581 Nancy2581

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2014 05:31PM justachapter wrote: Hi tcklme1, I currently have implants and have completed 2/33 or 35 treatments.  I read before that implants and radiation are not a good combo.  Not the implant itself, but the scar tissue, etc.  I saw the PS before I started rads and he said it would be an exception not to have issues and talked about many ways we could fix them after I was done.  He is going to see me right after, but said he wouldn't do anything for 6 months.  My breast surgeon came right behind him and told me not to do anything for at least a year.  With that said, he offered many options to fix them and how to make them symmetrical including the one that is not being treated.   I sometimes think it may come down to the Dr.'s expertise and experience with this stuff.  I am being treated at MDA, so he is very familiar with this type of stuff.  Is yours a regular PS or one that does a lot of work with women who have had BC?  Sorry you are going through this, and I really don't feel any of us should minimize our feelings based our diagnosis. Cancer is cancer, we are all in this together.
Posts.Title: Anyone with successful implant ...radiated breast? tcklme1 Moderators

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2014 05:16PM justachapter wrote: My mammo was February 11th, 10 days later (paperwork mix-up), news on February 26th, didn't use the surgeons recommended went to a multidisciplinary (MD Anderson).  Dropped my information off March 1st, met Dr. on March 6th, surgery on March 12th.  If you can, find a multidisciplinary center everything is under one roof and it is an amazing approach and so much burden is removed.  Perfect example today I had a follow-up and my next step is radiation.  I already have implants (prior to dx) and was concerned about what I was reading about them.  More often than not there are complications with radiation.  I told my surgeon I wanted an appointment with the plastic surgeon.  Well after my surgical check-up the plastic surgeon came to my exam room and we had an appointment right then and there. It is hard, but as many often say, for us it is an emotional emergency to get surgery and get treatment moving, but often not an emergency.  Time frames become more important with chemo and radiation. Good luck!
Posts.Title: How long after diagnosis did you have surgery? Katrina5558 Kicks

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2014 01:41PM justachapter wrote: Hi Dkath70, It is hard, very hard to wait, worst part.  Actually I'm waiting for my pathology from surgery at the moment, will hear today or tomorrow.  I'm one of those who the Radiologist Dr said I'm fairly certain it is benign, so I'm in the court that Dr's really should wait until biopsy to say anything. If indeed it comes back as malignant do try and go to a hospital that specializes in cancer.  I am with MD Anderson (AZ) and the multi disciplinary approach takes away so much burden.  I have a nurse navigator and everything is set up for me, all appointments and all Dr's work together as a team.  Everything is under one roof and it just makes it all so much easier on the patient. Good Luck and will be watching for an update.

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2014 11:12PM - edited Mar 29, 2014 01:25PM by justachapter Great News Ddkath70. You are on a similar path I was on, had my surgical consult on a Thurs and was in surgery the following Wednesday.  My Dr's concern was I may need a second surgery as she didn't have much rooms for clear margins, but she did it first time.  Though 1mm, which scares me, but acceptable.  Anyhow, I meet with oncologist Monday and have my 1 month surgical follow-up on April 10th. After that I get clearance for radiation.  Not excited, but once you start all your treatment you are ready to do it and get everything over with and get back to life. Will be thinking about you!
Posts.Title: Freaked out and have no idea where to start Ddkath70 Holeinone

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2014 04:58PM - edited Mar 24, 2014 05:01PM by justachapter Hi Ddkath70, Sorry you too have become a member.  If you haven't already, go get a copy of your reports.  Not that you can understand them, but you will want your report and a CD for Mayo on Friday.  But more specifically, Yes it is invasive, it is small but I don't know how the radiologist can say it is aggressive without providing a little more information.   Two additional items he/she could have provided you was your ER/PR status and your grade.  Grade provides a bit more in terms of what the cells are doing. I am DCIS, but grade 3 which is  the aggressive type.  Also, I took people with me to the first few appointments when this was all so new to me, I was overwhelmed and still in shock that this was happening to me, but at this point I like to go alone.  Not sure why, but I do.   Keep me posted and HUGS!
Posts.Title: Freaked out and have no idea where to start Ddkath70 Holeinone

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2014 01:32PM justachapter wrote: Happy Weekend Ddkath,  Hope you do some pampering!  My appointment is with oncologist I think for future Tamoxifen. This is the first time I'm meeting her.  I have a breast surgeon I will meet with two more times, have a radiology team, oncologist who will take over my care including from surgeon when I feel comfortable with her (per surgeon) and a nurse navigator.  It is truly a team approach, hope it is that way at Mayo too.  I received my first set of pathology after biopsy and received a second about 4 days after surgery.  The only thing that changed was I went from grade 2 at biopsy to grade 3 after surgery.  I already knew my ER and PR. Surgery wasn't bad at all, I was down a few days.  I took pain pills for a day and switched to Tylenol as I'm just sensitive to side effects.  It is still healing though, still swollen, still a little sore and get those zingers from nerve regeneration.  It is itchy as well, which means healing.  Scar is on side (mine was at 3:00 position) and only about 1.5".  She was even able to glue it so less scarring. Radiation for me will be 6 weeks.  5 weeks of daily full breast and then 1 week of daily boosts.   Get through your surgery and then you are in a holding pattern waiting for healing.  Still meeting with Dr's, but have a 4-6 weeks of healing.

HUGS!

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2014 02:56PM justachapter wrote: Hi Nikkito, My Dr. called me with the positive biopsy on Feb 26, met with imaging place to get report and welcome to cancer 101 on Feb 28.  Had already decided to go to MD Anderson and dropped everything off (imaging place had it all prepared) on March 1.  First appt with surgeon was March 6, MRI March 10, Surgery March 12.  I've already met with radiologist, have a planning meeting tomorrow.  Meet with oncologist on March 31.  Had my surgical f/u this morning. If it comes back positive and you have a multidisciplinary cancer center in your area usually a NCI designated one go to one of those.  They makes things less burdensome and are cutting edge.  Best wishes.

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2014 02:48AM justachapter wrote: Ddkath-Sounds like you are doing well and I so hear you on moving to the next chapter.  Having those friends who will be with you to the end is very important too.  Everyone is there with words in the beginning, but it is those special few who will see you to the finish line!   Finally started rads today and I think the month that I had to think about all this, sent me over the edge today.  I went into panic attack mode, racing heart, my blood pressure was the highest it has ever been.  Many things going on (had my dry run and my first rad today) and a few other changes.  Anyhow, I was able to get pulled from the ledge before they sent me to the ER :).  I will take a Xanax tomorrow before I go in. Nikko how are you doing?  And hope everyone else on this thread is doing well.
Posts.Title: Freaked out and have no idea where to start Ddkath70 Holeinone

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2014 10:01AM - edited Mar 21, 2014 10:04AM by justachapter Keep us posted Nikkito and ddkath70 today.  I think back to the day when I found out and was in a fog, but 3 weeks later things are very different and my job is to get through this and back to my boring life. Nikkito, my surgery was 9 days ago and I'm doing great.  Still swollen still sore, but back to the day to day grind add in a bunch of appointments.  I'd say that is what changes your life so much with this, all the appointments become your job in the first few weeks.  Well, it extends beyond that as I haven't started rads yet, but keeping track of appointments has kept me busy.  Thankful I am with a great network that does it all for me. I do hope that both of you get good news and aren't on this journey, but if you are this is a great place.  It keeps me sane to come read.  If I'm feeling sorry for myself I come read here. My life is a bit different at the moment and for those around me, their life continues without this little interruption.  HUGS!
Posts.Title: Freaked out and have no idea where to start Ddkath70 Holeinone

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2014 11:56PM justachapter wrote: That seems like very little info.  I was given size, type, grade, ER and PR from my biopsy.  You never have a complete dx until surgery because biopsy is a sample.  My grade and classification changed a bit after surgery.  Unless you have a full pathology report with those items Mayo won't be able to provide any additional information until surgery. I'm also very thankful that once I met my surgeon I was in surgery in less than a week.  Really the worst part of this is waiting, because we want to move forward and move on from this part of our lives.
Posts.Title: Freaked out and have no idea where to start Ddkath70 Holeinone

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2014 11:38AM justachapter wrote: You have to do what is right for you. Going back in for the DCIS it depends on how much tissue they will take out. I was told for me (small breasted) if they had to go back in I would have had a big pocket of empty space and needed to do some type of reconstruction.  Mastectomy has it's own set of issues. My friend had one and is still working on the symmetry part as it was just one side.  She is going in for additional surgery later this month.  And you loose all feeling and sensitivity.  Going the chemo/radiation route is very time consuming. I know you have to do chemo, but where does radiation play into this for you?  My radiation will be 6 weeks, I think 33 treatments.  Will find out the final plans for that after my 1 month surgical follow-up this week.   And for me, I have implants, nursing 3 babies made a mess of me and no clothes fit.  So 6 years ago I had implants to get back what I had lost.  I'm at huge risk of having capsular contraction on that side after radiation and will have to have surgery to fix it.  They wait 6 months as it takes 6-12 months for everything to settle down after radiation. Take one day at a time, look at all your options, pro's and con's and what is important to you at this moment.  I'm not sure how old you are, but you said you are very young.  You have a great team of Dr's and are at a great facility. I can tell you I have days where I look at this as something to get through and move back to my normal "boring" life. But, I also have days of anxiety.  The odds of this happening are small, what next? I'm a total glass half full type person too. It just really changes you in so many ways. I am thankful that I meet so many wonderful people each time I go into clinic.  I am getting to know some that I see often.  I also see very sick people and am thankful my diagnosis is totally curable.  My goal is to do what I have to do, to close this chapter and hopefully never worry about it again.  HUGS!
Posts.Title: Freaked out and have no idea where to start Ddkath70 Holeinone

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2014 04:58PM justachapter wrote: Hi Dd, You will go up and down and all around for awhile.  Even now I'm in a strange funk because I've been in  a holding pattern for a few weeks.  Things starting moving full steam ahead in a week or so.  Time to think isn't always the best when you are ready to get this behind you. I want to echo something 70 mentioned.  Do you have a nurse navigator at Mayo?  I have one and the first thing she said to me and I hold it close as I've encountered it a bit already.  "This is the time for you to be selfish and focus on YOU."  Do not worry about anyone else's feelings or making them feel better about your situation.  One thing, I didn't want anyone who had been unkind to me, to be nice because of this.  That happened with a neighbor, she sent me a text the day I had surgery and I never responded.  She was upset yada yada.  Really, made my situation about her.  You don't have time for that, you have work ahead! Let those who want to help, help (hard for me as I'm better at helping others) and let those who want to shower you with love do it.  I find comfort in my inner circle. And when you are ready, even when you aren't as it isn't easy for any of us, send the word, I'd love to meet up with you and meet some other AZ ladies I see on this thread. HUGS!
Posts.Title: Freaked out and have no idea where to start Ddkath70 Holeinone

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2014 10:40PM justachapter wrote: There are calcifications and cluster(s) of microcalcifications.  Calcifications are not alarming, a cluster of microcalcifications often leads to a biopsy.  Not all as often there is a pattern to what is suspicious.  I had one cluster and the Radiology Dr. who did my sterotactic biopsy said it was probably benign in a convincing way and most are.  But, mine was not.  It was early DCIS, but the highest grade. As you will find out here 80% are benign so your odds are higher for  B9 outcome!
Posts.Title: Only one cluster of calcifications bunny78 KorynH

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2014 02:52PM justachapter wrote: Good Luck Dkath! Thinking of you, you are in the pre-op area now will get happy juice in an hour!  Hope it goes smoothly and you can move onto the next step! xoxxoxo, from AZ!
Posts.Title: Freaked out and have no idea where to start Ddkath70 Holeinone

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2014 04:26PM justachapter wrote: Hugs Ddkath.  Isn't there someone that can explain your path report to you?  Mine was done at an imaging place, but anyone who has a biopsy has a follow-up appointment and because mine was positive a nurse met with me, explained what everything meant and what the likely treatment would be.  I was given a binder, lots of information, calendar for appointments and everything was put in a nice canvas bag.  Again they also prepared  all my paperwork and slides. If you are going to be really stressed the next few days, (I was during me 6 day wait to see my surgeon) I requested some anti-anxiety meds.  I wasn't sleeping and food was not appealing.  I lost 5lbs those first 2 weeks.  My Dr gave me a short course of Xanax and that was all I needed to get me over the hump. Hang in there and feel free to vent away.  I don't want to jump to conclusions so can't help on the pathology.

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2014 12:00AM justachapter wrote: Dd, So glad things went well.  Get some rest and I'm glad you will have your path before the weekend.  Praying for good results. 79, great news and I'd love to be heading to Mexico with fruity drinks for 2 weeks.  Enjoy every minute and great news on your husband!
Posts.Title: Freaked out and have no idea where to start Ddkath70 Holeinone

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2014 07:41PM justachapter wrote: Dd, Well that sucks, no other way to say it without using profanities.  I'm so glad you are at Mayo and it seems like they work similar to MD then?  My situation isn't comparable to your's but as someone wrote above, it is all a shock it is all so very hard to digest in the beginning.  Your life has literally been turned upside down and until your have a plan it is hard to digest.  Once you do, anxiety, etc. seems to calm down.  It still isn't easy, you were dealt a hand of cards you never asked, nor wanted.  But, you are strong because you have no choice and you will get through this. Do not hesitate to ask for anxiety meds, take them when needed they are truly a godsend when you feel like things are out of control.  May hugs from the other side of the valley and I'm not that far if you ever want to chat or meet up.
